parts.text:
```json
{
  "application": "Spack",
  "details": {
    "scheduler": "Slurm",
    "slurm_partition": "hotel",
    "slurm_nodes": 1,
    "slurm_tasks_per_node": 1,
    "slurm_cpus_per_task": 8,
    "slurm_time": "01:00:00",
    "spack_version": "0.17.3",
    "spack_instance_name": "cpu",
    "spack_instance_dir": "/cm/shared/apps/spack/0.17.3/cpu",
    "spack_package": "cmake@3.21.4",
    "spack_compiler": "intel@19.1.1.217",
    "spack_variants": "~doc +ncurses +openssl +ownlibs ~qt",
    "spack_dependencies": "^ncurses@6.2/$(spack find --format '{hash:7}' ncurses@6.2 % ${SPACK_COMPILER})",
    "spack_spec": "cmake@3.21.4 % intel@19.1.1.217 ~doc +ncurses +openssl +ownlibs ~qt ^ncurses@6.2/$(spack find --format '{hash:7}' ncurses@6.2 % intel@19.1.1.217)",
    "intel_license_file": "40000@elprado.sdsc.edu:40200@elprado.sdsc.edu",
    "system_name": "tscc",
    "scheduler_module": "slurm",
    "module_list": [
      "slurm",
      "cpu",
      "intel/19.1.1.217"
    ]
  }
}
```

The script uses Spack, a package manager for scientific software, to install CMake version 3.21.4 using the Intel compiler. It runs on a Slurm cluster and utilizes the `hotel` partition. The script specifies the number of nodes, tasks per node, and CPUs per task, along with a runtime limit.  It loads the necessary modules for Slurm, the Spack instance, and the Intel compiler. After installation, the script refreshes the Lmod module tree for Spack and submits a follow-up job to install Eigen version 3.4.0.0. 

This script demonstrates a typical workflow for managing scientific software using Spack, utilizing a cluster resource manager like Slurm to allocate resources and dependencies.
